importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the incident involving the Houthi rebels detaining UN employees in Sanaa, marking a significant escalation in the conflict over international humanitarian operations in Yemen.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeline of the detention and subsequent UN response highlights the immediate and ongoing crisis in humanitarian access to Yemen's conflict-affected regions.

keyTakeAways: Iranian-backed Houthi rebels detained 20 UN employees in Sanaa, including five Yemenis and 15 international staff, in a facility located in the Hada neighborhood.
The rebels confiscated all communications equipment, including phones, servers, and computers, from the facility, disrupting humanitarian operations.
The detained staff belong to multiple UN agencies such as the World Food Program, UNICEF, and the Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs.
This incident follows a broader pattern of Houthi crackdowns against UN and international personnel, including earlier detentions in Saada and Hodeida provinces.
A World Food Program worker died in detention in Saada earlier in the year, underscoring the dangers faced by humanitarian workers.
The UN has suspended operations in Saada and relocated its top humanitarian coordinator to Aden, reflecting the deteriorating security environment.
The Houthis have repeatedly accused UN staff of espionage, claims the UN denies, indicating a deepening of mistrust and political tension.
The UN is actively engaging with the Houthis and other parties to resolve the situation and restore full control of its facilities.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Iranian-backed Houthi rebels in Yemen detained 20 United Nations employees, including five Yemeni nationals and 15 international staff, at a facility in the Hada neighborhood of Sanaa. The rebels confiscated all communication equipment, severely disrupting humanitarian operations. The detained staff include personnel from key UN agencies such as the World Food Program, UNICEF, and the Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs. This incident follows a long-standing pattern of Houthi crackdowns on international organizations, including previous detentions in Saada and Hodeida, where a WFP worker died in detention earlier in the year. The UN has suspended operations in Saada and relocated its top humanitarian coordinator to Aden due to escalating security risks. The Houthis have accused the detained staff of being spies, a claim the UN firmly denies. The UN is actively engaging with the Houthis and other stakeholders to resolve the situation and restore full access to facilities and operations.
title: Yemen’s Houthi rebels detain 20 UN employees and confiscate equipment
